segments.key_quote: What is this extraordinary time? What is going to happen?
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verses 17 and 18 of Srimad Bhagavatam, describing Yudhishthira Maharaj's observations of bad omens and disturbances in nature, questioning the meaning of these signs.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from verse 17 to 21 of the 14th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. These verses will describe Yudhishthira Maharaj observing some bad omens, further description of that. The 17th verse: Suryam Hata Prabham Pashya Graham Ardham Mitho Divi Sa Sankulair Bhutad Suryam Hata Prabham Pashya Graham Ardham Mitho Divi Sankulair Bhutad politician Soral Ganeir Jwellite Eva Rohd-si. The meaning of this verse is, "The rays of the sun are declining and the stars appear to be fighting amongst themselves. Confused living entities appear to be ablaze and weeping." The 18th verse: nadyo nadasscha Subhitah Saramsicha Mannala Ch brakes 12-19end. The meaning of this verse is, "Rivers, tributaries, ponds, reservoirs and mind are all perturbed. Butter no longer ignites fire." What is this extraordinary time? What is going to happen?

segments.key_quote: The calves do not suck the teats of the cows, nor do the cows give milk. They are standing crying, tears in their eyes.
segments.summary: The speaker explains verse 19, focusing on the distress of cows and bulls as a bad omen, highlighting the importance of cows in Vedic culture.
segments.transcript: So, Yudhishthira Maharaj is describing to Bhima the bad omens that he is observing. Rivers are disturbed, ponds and reservoirs of water are disturbed. How they are so sensitive to note all these indications of something inauspicious or undesirable that is going to happen. People were living in harmony with nature. This is the point I mentioned in the earlier session and I am repeating that, that we are meant to live according to a certain design of the Supreme Lord in this material world. People have become indifferent to nature. Of course, they suffer calamities and they do take note of that. But then, even before a calamity occurs, the bad omens or the symptoms of such calamitous happenings in the future, that nobody is able to, most people are not able to recognize that. It is common knowledge in the Vedic times. So, Yudhishthira Maharaj is asking Bhima, what is this extraordinary time? What is going to happen? The 19th verse, na pibanti sthanam vatsa, na duhyanti ca matara, rudanti ashrumukha gaavo, na hrishyanti hrishabhavraje. The meaning of this verse is, "The calves do not suck the teats of the cows, nor do the cows give milk. They are standing crying, tears in their eyes." And, the bhima says, what is going to happen? What is happening? Then, they have had these long cuckoo calls, and the bulls take no pleasure in the pasturing grounds.

segments.key_quote: In the Bhagavad Gita it is particularly said, Gauraksha, special mention is given that it is the duty of householders to give special protection to the cows.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the importance of cow protection in Vedic culture, emphasizing the special care and protection cows deserve, referencing Bhagavad Gita.
segments.transcript: Especially in the Vedic culture, the cows and the calves and the bulls were treated by the people who owned them, who reared them, as their own children. This is very important. Among all the domestic animals, the cows were treated as seriously, as nicely, as caringly as their own children. And in the Bhagavad Gita it is particularly said, Gauraksha, special mention is given that it is the duty of householders to give special protection to the cows, though one should never harm any other creature, still specifically the cows had to be given special extra care, extra protection than the other animals, domestic animals. So Yudhishthira is marred, marking, cows do not suck the teeth of the cows, why? Because the cows are not giving milk. And why are they not giving milk? Because they are standing there crying tears in their eyes, something calamitous is going to happen. The cows are also sensing and Yudhishthira is noticing this. And the bulls, they used to happily go to the pasturing grounds and graze, but now they are not taking any pleasure in grazing. They seem to be disinterested. There are also four boardings on calamitous happening.

segments.key_quote: Deities seem to be crying in the temple, lamenting and perspiring.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses verse 20, describing the deities in the temples as crying and the overall atmosphere as devoid of beauty and happiness, foreshadowing a major calamity.
segments.transcript: The 20th verse, Daivathani Rudantiva Svidyanti Hi Ucchalanticha Ime Janapada Grama Purodhyana Akara Ashram. Ima Janapada Grama Purodhyana Akara Ashram. Ima Janapada Grama Purodhyana Akara Ashram. Ima Janapada Grama Purodhyana Akara Ashram. Ima Janapada Grama Purodhyana Akara Ashram Aaha. Brashta Shriyo Niranandaha, Niranandaha Kimmagha Darsha Yantinaha. The meaning of this verse is that deities seem to be crying in the temple, lamenting and perspiring. See even the deities are not just some statues in the temples. They are actually personalities. Verses 10 and 11. He was a tactician. The Prophet is also called a tactician. who are personally present and only in advanced devotee can see the deities seem to be crying in the temples. And these deities also Yudhishthira Maharaj is saying they seem about to leave the temple and go away. All the cities, villages, towns, gardens, mines and hermitages are now devoid of beauty and bereft of all happiness. The entire atmosphere is very sad. There is a sadness that is spread everywhere and natural beauty is absent in gardens, mines, hermitages that natural beauty is missing now. And there seems to be no happiness anywhere. I do not know what sort of calamities are now awaiting us. Yudhishthira Maharaj is telling Bhima. What kind of calamities are we going to face now? We do not know. But certainly there is going to be some major calamity.
